Michigan Initial Health & Safety Training Module B
Section 2: Prevention & Response to Emergencies Due to Food & Allergic Reactions

What Can Child Care Programs Do?

Let’s discuss what child care programs can do to keep children safe from responses to food allergies.

  • Write a Policy
  • Write a Plan
  • Avoid
  • Read
  • Notify
  • Post
  • Know the Signs
  • Know the Location

Write a Policy for your site

Child care sites are encouraged to develop written policies that discuss what steps they will take to recognize and manage food allergies.

Write a Care Plan for each Child

When a center or home cares for a child with known food allergies they should write a specific plan of care on how they will manage and treat that child’s food allergy. In the Support Material section at the end of this chapter there is an excellent sample titled ‘Food Allergy & Anaphylaxis Emergency Care Plan”.

Avoid foods a child is allergic to

Be careful to avoid cross contamination in food preparation areas. In the Support Material section at the end of this chapter there is a link to a ‘Prevent Cross-Contact’ poster that you can hang on the wall of your site. If feasible, when a known food allergy is identified it is best to not serve that food to any child at the site. In some circumstances it may be preferred the parent provide the foods the child is eating.

Read food labels for ingredients

Many times there are hidden ingredients in foods. Therefore it is important to read all food labels carefully for all contents.

Notify other parents

Make sure other parents know to avoid the foods children are allergic to when providing snacks. If a child receives medical treatment, as a result of a medical condition such as an allergic reaction. licensed providers in both centers and homes must report this to LARA.

Post a list of all children with food allergies

Post a list of all children with food allergies and what food is their allergy for staff preparing meals and providers serving meals to children so they avoid these foods. List should not be public to others. Consider posting the list on the inside of a cabinet or adding a cover sheet to protect children’s privacy from non-caregivers.

Know the signs and symptoms of reactions

Educate staff to recognize the signs and symptoms of food allergies and anaphylactic reactions.

Know the location of and how to administer an EpiPen

Know the location of and how to administer an EpiPen. Educate all staff caring for children where EpiPens are stored and how to administer them.
